millsfield:images_texts:
win your wings
as a
PAN AM
STEWARDESS
PAN AMERICAN
WORLD'S MOST EXPERIENCED AIRLINE

BUT FIRST...
ARE YOU ELIGIBLE?
First things first: are
you eligible? Check yourself
against the following list of qualifications for proba-
tionary Stewardess..
1. Age 21 thru 26 at the time employed by Pan
American.
2. Height: 5'3" to 5'8" (1.60 to 1.73 meters).
3. Weight: 105 to 135 pounds (48 to 61 kg.), well
proportioned.
4. Marital Status: Single.
5. Education: High school graduate (two years of
college preferred).
6. Languages: Applicants must be fluent in English
and have a reasonable knowledge of one of the follow-
ing languages: French,
Spanish,
Italian,
German,
Portuguese,
Finnish,
Dutch,
Swedish,
Danish,
Norwegian,
Turkish, Russian. Japanese, Chinese, Arabic,
Hindustani or Greek.
7. Must be a citizen of the United States or able to
obtain an immigration visa to the United States.
8. Must be able to obtain and maintain passport, visas
and U.S. resident status, and be able to travel freely
and
perform duties as assigned while in all lands
served by Pan American.
9. Must be in excellent health - able, in fact, to pass
a flight medical examination and receive various in-
oculations. Vision must be at least 20/50 in one eye
and no worse than 20/100 in the other eye. Both eyes
must be correctible to 20/30. Eyeglasses and contact
lenses are not permitted while on duty.
Must have good posture and appearance.
11.
Must be of good moral character.
12.
Must have a pleasant speaking voice and habit-
ually use good English.
13.
Must have a pleasing personality, poise, tact and
diplomacy - and possess a genuine liking for people.
hard work.
Must be willing, adaptable and prepared for
15.
Must be able to swim.
16. Although Stewardesses are normally based in the
U.S., applicants must be willing to accept assignments
outside the continental United States should the need
arise.
HOW DO YOU APPLY?
Now, if you feel that you
Depending on whether you
are located in the
Eastern or Western part of the
United States, you should write directly to either the
Employment Office,
Pan American World Airways,
Hangar 14, JFK International Airport, Jamaica, New
York 11430 or the Employment Office, Pan American
World Airways, International Airport, San Francisco,
California 94128. Applicants who are in the New York
City or San Francisco area are invited to apply in
person to either of the above offices any weekday
morning.
If you are in the Miami area, you are invited to write
or visit the Employment Supervisor, Pan American
36th Street,
B idi live outside the Use, Viami, File da 30591
nearest Pan Am office and ask when an interviewer
will be in vour area. You must pass a check of quali-
fications-height, weight, languages, etc.-before being
interviewed. Travel and other personal expenses in-
volved in being interviewed are paid by the applicant
Once accepted, you'll undergo an intensive training
course at Pan Am's Stewardess Training School.
WHAT TRAINING DO YOU RECEIVE?
Training
takes five weeks and includes extensive classroom worl
in a variety of subjects-plus actual training under
in-flight conditions in a specially built replica of a
Clipper cabin interior, called a "mock-up."
The sub-
jects you'll study are:
• Crew conduct
Personal grooming
• First aid
• Customer relations
• Baby-care
• Passenger service
• U.S. Customs Regulations
• Currency conversion
• Aircraft documentation
• Aircraft familiarization
• Emergency equipment and procedures
• In-flight food preparation, meal service and beverage
service (conducted in airplane mock-up)
• Theory of flight, navigation, communications
Printed in U.S.A.
F-414-8/65
Clipper. Trade Mark Reg. U.S. Pat. Off. Copyright 1965. Pan American Airways, inc

WHAT DOES A STEWARDESS DO? A
Stewardess
on a Pan American Clipper is a hostess in the broad-
est sense - the person who welcomes our passengers -
and continues to make them feel at home from takeoff
to touchdown. She's a girl of many talents - an engag-
ing conversationalist ... expert on foreign currency,
customs and
passport regulations. proficient at
whipping up a delicious meal and serving it miles up
in the sky.
A Pan Am Stewardess radiates her genuine interest
in others.
knows how to reassure the occasional
passenger experiencing a touch of "first-flight jitters"
... can give first-aid in emergencies - even fill in as
a children's nurse, helping with formula preparations.
Being a good stewardess is hard work - but fascinat-
ing, enjoyable work for the girl who really likes to
work with people. Before you apply, ask yourself this
question: Am I right for the job and is the job right
for me?
WHAT ABOUT SALARY? The starting pay for
Stewardess is $301.50 per month - as high as $346.73
upon completion of training! With additional increases
every six months from date of employment, a Stew-
ardess can earn as much as $482.48 per month within
three years.
Pan American Stewardesses have plenty of room for
advancement, too. A Stewardess may be promoted to
Purser - the person in charge of an aircraft's cabin
crew - even before she has reached the top of her own
pay scale. Promotions are based on seniority and abil-
ity - and Pursers earn up to $607.78 per month!
In addition to the salaries mentioned above, Steward-
esses and Pursers receive substantial compensation tor
hours over 70 in each month. Eighty-five (85) hours
constitutes the normal monthly
flight time.
WHERE ARE YOU BASED? Stewardesses normally
are based in New York, Miami, San Francisco, Seattle
or Houston and fly to destinations round the world -
Europe, Asia, the Pacific, Africa, the Middle East, the
Caribbean and South America. If new bases are
established, first choice will
go to Stewardesses with
he prest ded is naturally, and transportation will
WHERE DO YOU FLY? Generally, flight service per-
sonnel are rotated from one route to another - with
periodic layovers at designated points which change
from time to time.
However,
flight service personnel
are able to exercise preferences for monthly flying
schedules in accordance with their seniority and qual-
ifications. In all cases, lodgings, food and transporta-
tion are provided by Pan Am. Present schedules keep
Stewardesses flying about 15 days a month - with
trips ranging in length from 1 day for the New York-
Bermuda round trip to 12 days or more on a swing
through South Africa or South America.
The routes
you travel are the famous routes of the Flying Clip-
pers - a network that links 86 lands on 6 continents!
Wherever you go, you'll have ample free time for
sightseeing and shopping.
HOW ABOUT ANNUAL LEAVE? In addition to reg-
ular time off between flights, cabin attendants earn
30 days of paid vacation per year. While on annual
vacation,
Stewardesses and eligible relatives are en-
titled to fly anywhere over the Company's routes for
only 10% of the regular fare.
WHAT ABOUT HOUSING?
That's up to you.
but generally, Stewardesses perfer to share an apart-
ment which cuts individual costs considerably. Since
your full pay begins the day you commence Steward-
ess training. Pan American does not provide employee
housing. but we are always happy to help newly ar-
rived Stewardesses by
arranging hotel reservations
and by
providing information concerning apartment
vacancies.
etc.
Each new Stewardess
should bring
money of her own -$300 will do nicely - as a re-
serve fund and to see her through the first two or
three weeks until she receives her first paycheck.
WHO PAYS FOR THE UNIFORMS?
For the first
year. you do. After that, Pan American furnishes any
necessary replacements. Currently, the complete uni-
form with accessories costs about $265.00. If you wish,
we can help arrange a bank loan for you to pay the
initial costs. You can take up to a full year to repay
this loan from salary deductions of $22.40 per month.

your career in
PAN AM
BLUE
Wherever in the world you go,
people know that as a girl in the tailored blue uni-
form of a Pan Am Stewardess, you lead an exciting
life. Your heart is in the clouds ... your chosen
career is stimulating - free from workaday monot-
ony and far, far more than "just a job." You wear
your blue and gold Pan Am Stewardess wings with
pride. The whole wide, wonderful world is your
"place of business," and your days are filled with the
romance of far-away, exotic lands ... the adventure
of our ever-changing world.
the warmth of
human contact with the peoples of all nations.
You'll fly to Africa, Europe and Asia - from Jo-
hannesburg to Helsinki.. from Chicago to Hong
Kong! Or to the glamorous cities of Latin America.
The capitals of the world soon become as familiar
as your own home town.
You enjoy the prestige of a profession that is widely
- and
deservedly - acclaimed as glamorous. You
meet the most fascinating international celebrities.
You can take keen satisfaction from knowing that
when you fly with Pan American you're flying with
the
"World's Most Experienced Airline"
• . . and
you know, too, that a large measure of Pan Amer-
ican's leadership can be traced to the world-famous
hospitality of cabin attendants like yourself.
It is Pan American's policy to employ the best
qualified people available without regard to race,
creed, color or national origin.
